That's the wrong direction.  I really don't see this stock doing anything but settling back to 12 until they announce a great thing that will move the forward PE in the right direction.  What am I missing. I want a reason to buy this again, but I can't find any, other than a short squeeze, which, without fundamentals, is just a Gamestop play that can cut your fingers by holding.  A few insiders buying at a discount of 10.50 doesn't tempt me.  Especially with other chip sector stocks, or even holding an ETF like Vanguard Information Technology Index Fund (VGT) for the last 6 months you'd be so much wealthier. Infineon's Q3 FY24 earnings call transcript came out today.  Opening remarks acknowledged healthy consumer demand in China, but tepid Western markets. They confirmed a SiC revenue target of 600 million euros this fiscal year, up 20% from last year, but then the CEO seemed to walk that back a bit in Q&A.  Kulim 3 (200 mm SiC fab/module) will "open" this week and slowly ramp as determined by customer demand.  There was an interesting question asked about VW (referring to ON's recent PR announcing Onsemi as the primary supplier for VW's SCC Platform).  SiC device prices are dropping - which is normal for improving economics as the shift to 200mm wafers takes place.  Infineon now is offering "fusion" modules that combine silicon and SiC power devices and already has collected two design wins. It's hard to predict what this means for AEHR sales to IFNNY in AEHR's FY25.  Maybe one more XP with fully integrated and automated aligner.  And a bunch of Waferpaks.

For decades, silicon has been the main material of electronics, but in the continuous path towards miniaturization it seems destined to be abandoned soon due to some of its intrinsic limitations. To be able to control a series of physical phenomena useful in some new sectors, such as photonics, it would be necessary to be able to model the inside of thin sheets of silicon at nanometric dimensions. An objective that has so far been impossible, so much so that it has prompted the search for possible substitutes for silicon. However, even the possible candidate materials present various obstacles. The new technique, which uses very short laser pulses, allows us to engrave thin layers (silicon wafers) with great precision, reaching dimensions 10 times smaller than what has been possible so far, reaching 100 nanometres. The technique which, the researchers observe , can be applied on relatively large surfaces and in a very efficient way. It could therefore pave the way for new applications of silicon and the most interesting ones, according to Tokel ‚Äúcould concern photonics, in particular metamaterials and photonic crystals‚Äù.
The doors are open to use silicon in ways that were previously impossible Thanks to lasers capable of digging inside it on a nanoscale
